spans.content: ABSTRACT.In 2015,I. Soprunov and A. Zvavitch have shown how to use the Bernstein-Khovanskii-
Kushnirenko theorem to derive non-negativity of a certain bilinear form
convex bodies. Together with C. Saroglou, they proved non-negativity of
amongall polytopes.It is conjectured the characterization further holds among all convex bodies.
Towards this conjecture,several necessary conditions on
We give a new necessary condition, expressed with isoperimetric ratios, which provides a further step
towards a (conjectural) characterization of simplices among a certain subclass of convex bodies.
The isoperimetric ratio of a convex body
-Hausdorff measure of its topological boundary). A classcal result in convex geometry, the
isoperimetric inequality,states that Euclidean balls minimize this ratio,and are the only minimizers.
On the other side,the isoperimetric ratio can bearbitrarily large.However,note this ratio is not affine
invariant.Following K.Ball(see [Ba,Theorem 2]),consider instead the affine invariant quantity:
I s o ( K ) = \operatorname* { m i n } _ { T \in O ( n ) } \frac { | \partial ( T K ) | _ { n - 1 } ^ { n } } { | T K | _ { n } ^ { n - 1 } } ,
where the minimum runs over the orthogonal group
I s o ( K ) \leq I s o ( \Delta _ { n } ) ,
yielding a reverse isoperimetric inequality. Additionally, it was proved in [Ba] that
result can be reformulated within the language of mixed volumes as folows :for any convex body

\begin{array} { r } { V _ { n } ( K [ n - 1 ] , \mathcal { E } ) ^ { n } V _ { n } ( \Delta _ { n } ) ^ { n - 1 } \leq V _ { n } ( \Delta _ { n } [ n - 1 ] , \mathcal { E } ) ^ { n - 1 } V _ { n } ( K ) ^ { n - 1 } . } \end{array}
Another interesting inequality of mixed volumes involving
was derived by I. Soprunov and
A. Zvavitch (see [SZ16]), using the Bernstein-Kushnirenko-Khovanskii theorem (see [Ber75],[Kho78],
[Kul),and an inequality from real algebraic geometry called Bezout inequality:

\begin{array} { r } { \mathcal { H } L _ { 1 } , L _ { 2 } \in K ^ { n } : \quad V _ { n } ( L _ { 1 } , L _ { 2 } , \Delta _ { n } [ n - 2 ] ) V _ { n } ( \Delta _ { n } ) \leq V _ { n } ( L _ { 1 } , \Delta _ { n } [ n - 1 ] ) V _ { n } ( L _ { 2 } , \Delta _ { n } [ n - 1 ] ) . } \end{array}
This set of inequalities (called Bezout inequalities in [SZ16]) can be thought of as non-negativity of
F _ { \Delta } ( A , B ) = V _ { n } ( A , \Delta _ { n } [ n - 1 ] ) V _ { n } ( B , \Delta _ { n } [ n - 1 ] ) - V _ { n } ( A , B , \Delta _ { n } [ n - 2 ] ) V _ { n } ( \Delta _ { n } ) .

ABSTRACT.In 2015,I. Soprunov and A. Zvavitch have shown how to use the Bernstein-Khovanskii-
Kushnirenko theorem to derive non-negativity of a certain bilinear form
convex bodies. Together with C. Saroglou, they proved non-negativity of
amongall polytopes.It is conjectured the characterization further holds among all convex bodies.
Towards this conjecture,several necessary conditions on
We give a new necessary condition, expressed with isoperimetric ratios, which provides a further step
towards a (conjectural) characterization of simplices among a certain subclass of convex bodies.
The isoperimetric ratio of a convex body
-Hausdorff measure of its topological boundary). A classcal result in convex geometry, the
isoperimetric inequality,states that Euclidean balls minimize this ratio,and are the only minimizers.
On the other side,the isoperimetric ratio can bearbitrarily large.However,note this ratio is not affine
invariant.Following K.Ball(see [Ba,Theorem 2]),consider instead the affine invariant quantity:
I s o ( K ) = \operatorname* { m i n } _ { T \in O ( n ) } \frac { | \partial ( T K ) | _ { n - 1 } ^ { n } } { | T K | _ { n } ^ { n - 1 } } ,
where the minimum runs over the orthogonal group
I s o ( K ) \leq I s o ( \Delta _ { n } ) ,
yielding a reverse isoperimetric inequality. Additionally, it was proved in [Ba] that
result can be reformulated within the language of mixed volumes as folows :for any convex body

\begin{array} { r } { V _ { n } ( K [ n - 1 ] , \mathcal { E } ) ^ { n } V _ { n } ( \Delta _ { n } ) ^ { n - 1 } \leq V _ { n } ( \Delta _ { n } [ n - 1 ] , \mathcal { E } ) ^ { n - 1 } V _ { n } ( K ) ^ { n - 1 } . } \end{array}
Another interesting inequality of mixed volumes involving
was derived by I. Soprunov and
A. Zvavitch (see [SZ16]), using the Bernstein-Kushnirenko-Khovanskii theorem (see [Ber75],[Kho78],
[Kul),and an inequality from real algebraic geometry called Bezout inequality:

This set of inequalities (called Bezout inequalities in [SZ16]) can be thought of as non-negativity of
F _ { \Delta } ( A , B ) = V _ { n } ( A , \Delta _ { n } [ n - 1 ] ) V _ { n } ( B , \Delta _ { n } [ n - 1 ] ) - V _ { n } ( A , B , \Delta _ { n } [ n - 2 ] ) V _ { n } ( \Delta _ { n } ) .
